By the way, to whoever is reading this and thinking "well I don't much like liberalism or conservatism", there are more than two political ideologies out there.

Do you really love capitalism and really hate the state? (American) libertarianism could be for you
Do you think that capitalism is pretty destructive and that it should be controlled as much as possible? Social democracy could be your game
Do you think capitalism is really bad for people? You could always try socialism
Do you hate capitalism and also hate the state? You could go for libertarian socialism (which is actually where the term libertarian originated as a political ideology)
You can have markets without capitalism, you can have markets without the state, you can have capitalism without the state, you could have a strong state and heavy capitalism, you could have capitalism intertwined with the state!
That's not even to get into the social aspects of different positions
I mean you've got fascists, anarchists, ancaps, Leninists, syndicalists, populists, progressives, reactionaries, the list goes on. American politics cannot do justice to the nuances of political theory.

I seem to have transitioned from liberal to conservative as I've gone through my 20's.

At 19/20, I discovered marijuana and went full hippie. My father (a 60's flower child) gave me old comics from that era and the live Woodstock album. My car had incense burning in it constantly, my nights were filled with black light posters and White Rabbit playing softly through speakers. I could always be found with a joint in my mouth at parties, stoned out of my mind. I engaged in free love. My GPA was 1.02, and I was going to school for Game Design. Weed and liberal issues were all I talked about, and I was racking up arrests for drug charges.

Around 25, my life started to shift. I began dating a girl and realized I wanted to clean up my act and be an eventual husband she could be proud of. I stopped smoking weed, went back to school, and gradually the relics of my old self were replaced (also both drug charges were dropped). I graduated with a 3.34 GPA and my degree in Game Design before moving on to a Bachelors in Finance (3.96 and $0 debt!). My dress, speech and attitude went from The Dude to The Wolf of Wall Street (with less swearing). Now, at 31, I look back on that decade and smile. It has been quite the wild ride.

Now none of this is to say that 'liberal means druggie' or 'conservative means high GPA' or anything else like that. Not at all. Those were just accompanying factors of my life at the time. Heck, cannabis is still a major interest of mine, and I read about it frequently, even if I'm waiting on my first post-college job to light it up again (first time in 6 years!). But my views have shifted as I went through my education and learned more and more, and I'll always carry a little bit of that hippie in me, even if now it's beneath a three-piece suit.

One problem of US politics is that members of both parties identify themselves as liberals. But in reality, there is a distinction between:
> conservatives: favoring economic freedom but traditionally disfavoring personal freedom (example: abortion)
> progressives: favoring personal freedom but disfavoring too much economic freedom, hence higher taxes
> liberals: favoring both more economic freedom and personal freedom

Of course, the lines are always blurred, especially in American politics. 
> Progressivists can be liberals, when they support more economic freedom. 
> Conservatives can also be liberals, when they support more personal freedom.
> Socialists, who are still progressivists, are not in favor of extreme personal freedom: they are against gun ownership for example. Furthermore, they take measures against discrimination that other liberals (more often than not conservative-liberals) consider as a restriction of personal liberty.
> Libertarians are liberals, but they support a policy that is much closer to "laissez-faire" than traditional liberals.

All of this to say two things:
1) Politics are not black and white. They are mostly in different tones of grey.
2) the terms "conservative", "liberal" and "progressive" also depend on the context in which they are used. Today's conservatives are not the same as yesterday's conservatives. Times change, circumstances change and therefore, political ideologies change. It is clear than in an ultra progressive country, conservatives are closer to the center than in our current societies, and progressives are the equivalent of today's far left.

You need to distinct between liberal and progressive. They are not the same.

Liberalism is equal opportunity for all, unequal outcome for all. It’s pretty straightforward. For example, liberals would be supporting making better schools for Detroit’s school system, but would oppose those same kids getting into a school simply because of the color of their skin, or their religion.

Progressivism is equal opportunity for all with equal outcome. So a progressive would be completely on board with liberals in making Detroit schools better. They would also take affirmative action even further, and would support quotas demanding a certain amount of people based on their identity to be accepted into a school.

The train of thought on where these two areas of thought disagree relates to the concept of the American dream itself. The American dream at one point in its history was a land of *opportunity* for all where you could build your life there.

Liberals fought for women’s rights, to give them equal representation and therefore equal opportunity to men (or at least closer)

Liberals fought for civil rights, by making discrimination based on race illegal, and outlawing segregation.

Progressives have instituted things like affirmative action, welfare, and other more socialistic concepts in American govt.

I am not saying either is better. I think there needs to be help for people who were not given equal opportunity. But to often do we treat the symptoms of a bad society, rather than treat the source.

What I mean is that if Liberals and Progressives both focused on what we agree upon, then we could get a lot more done. Instead of spreading the help out to the symptoms or the outcome, more effort to even out the opportunity would make the American dream alive again.

Imagine a world with completely equal quality of schools for all. Crime rates the same in rich and poor communities, and programs given to the less fortunate to allow poorer kids the same *opportunities* as their richer peers.

America would be based on hard work and character. Instead, we don’t focus on the causes of inequality of opportunity, we focus on the symptoms of inequality of opportunity.

Just a huge LOL. Is it like with everything that you Americans tend to just do your own thing concerning definitions and units for a basis of discussion? Because as far as I am informed, those definitions of political ideologys given in the video are completely wrong, since they are confused with each other. There are actually three basic political ideologies:

1) Conservative/Right: The main principle is maintaining traditions and old values. Therefore conservatives propose strong authorities and a more or less free market with some regulations. They often oppose immigrations, multiculturalism and basically all form of radical "new thinking", since it does not fit with the supposed national and hierachic nature of humans.

2) Liberal/Libertarian: The main principle is aiming for a maximum of economical and individual freedom. Therfore liberals propose a minimalistic state government not intervening in the dynamics of the free market, but securing law and order towards both, the inside and the outside of the country. Libertarians even propose the absecence of a state in general and imagine a society fully shaped and kept in order by the principle of the "invisible hand" of the radical free market.

3) Socialist/Communist/Left: The main principle is aiming for justice and/or equality. Therefore the state should be empowered to enable a more just society by regulating the free market by, for example, regulating big corperations, imposing taxes on the rich, enabling social health care and other social policies etc. etc. Capitalism is seen as the root for inequality and must therefore be regulated or, for communists, even be abolished and replaced by a classless society without private property.
While some socialists aim for a planned economy, others aim for a anarchic type of "share-economy".

Basically there are different variations for each ideology, but these are the three general ideologies, on which one can build on further political and philsophical positions.

The liberalism described in this video is closer to socialism and planned economies, not liberal or free economies. The word liberalism comes from liberty, not equality.

Another factor that he didn't mention is urban vs. rural. I think it has to do with the nature of government spending in cities and how population density affects people's perception of that spending. For example, even in a perfect system where government spending for any particular area is directly proportional to the number of people who live there. In a rural area, spending would be less and the effects would be more subtle even if people received benefits from government programs and payed taxes in equal proportions. In areas with high population densities more people would equal more money and therefore a greater tangible impact of government spending in the form of large infrastructure projects, large universities, public transportation and public spaces. Also, living in close proximity to people who are of diverse ethnicities, incomes and disability status, you're more likely to encounter people who have a legitimate need for public assistance and have at least a more nuanced view of how public assistance should work. Even individuals who pay more in taxes than the direct benefit of these projects either utilize those themselves or at least can see the benefit directly and are less likely to see such programs as frivolous as a whole.

The way that my high school civics teacher explained political ideology, I think, was a fairly good explanation: there are three functions of government: to maintain order, promote equality, and secure freedoms. Your political orientation is based on how you prioritize these three functions, measured on a two-axis scale, with one axis being freedom vs. order, and the other being freedom vs. equality. Conservatives value order over freedom, and freedom over equality, while the reverse is true of liberals -- equality then freedom then order. Other political leanings include libertarians, who put freedom above all else, being split into the left and right schools based on which they rank second, order or equality (order for right libertarians, equality for left libertarians); socialists, who value equality over order and order over freedom; and communatarians, who value order over equality and equality over freedom. In addition, there are those that believe in only one of these functions of government, ignoring the others: anarchists, who believe in extreme freedom; authoritarians, who only care about maintaining order (this is where most pre-modern governments would fall, especially feudal ones; it is, unsurprisingly, unpopular with everyone except the ruling class), and Marxists, who only care about equality (note: while every "Communist" nation claims to be Marxist, in practice, they invariably end up being authoritarian, or, at best, communatarian. That being said, I do not believe Marxism to be a viable form of government, as enforcing radical equality takes a great deal of state centralization, which makes the system inherently vulnerable to dictatorial takeover). I'm surprised that you didn't mention this concept; it is fairly popular in civics textbooks.

All ideology in essence involves the substitution of alien (or incomplete) concepts or images for human subjectivity. Ideologies are systems of false consciousness in which people no longer see themselves directly as subjects in their relation to their world. Liberal, conservative, libertarian, authoritarian.
In reality, all these terms mean nothing.

For each political topic, you can lean into one of several directions.
But - and this is the important part - your political view as a whole rarely fits into any of these categories. As each topic requires individual assessment.
And since a political party's views are nothing but an average of the entirety of the party's members or the party's groups views.
A "liberal" may easily find himself in agreement with a "conservative" on any political topic. And a political party may strongly deviate from what it's supposed to represent.
Therefore, saying something along the lines of you are a "conservative" because you support more of the government spendings going into the military is nonsensical.

All people do when they look at this 2-dimensional political grid is to use personal stances on very few - and for some even minor - topics that are supposed to define your political ideology. But unless those topics are your main political concerns, you can agree or disagree with as much of those topics as you want in order to see which of the 4 directions you lean towards the most, it doesn't define your political view in the slightest.
A grid with 4 directions is a distorted picture of how political views are supposed to be looked at, just as much as a left-right spectrum is.

That is why a "liberal" party might actually be seen as a "conservative" one and the other way around, because they are neither of these categories. They are only so from a perspective of this very narrow-minded grid that pre-determines for you what is supposed to be important for you depending on the direction you lean towards.

That is also why statements like these are twisted:
"The Australian paradox: Our 'liberals' are the conservatives."
It's a false conclusion you can only arrive at when you have already made the mistake of accepting these 4 political directions as an absolute truth. Which they are not.

That is why these terms are meaningless. You might as well stand on the exact same point as someone else on such a political grid and you would still find that your political views are in heavy contrast to one another.
Saying a person or a party has "political ideology x" is a statement that relies on flawed logic and will therefore always leave you with a false output that - when compared with reality - will always bring you further away from the answer that this statement tried to give.

Just saying.

I think it's also important to point out that the "Left-Right" divide is a shorthand for a person's value of preserving a sociopolitical tradition versus creating sociopolitical change.
